reviews.author: Jorge

reviews.title: "Inspect, inspect, inspect!"
reviews.text:
When I first bought the unit and assembled it, I did so without inspecting parts first. The bottom of the charcoal side was badly warped and the lid would not close properly- meaning no seal whatsoever. I called Lowes and they replaced the charcoal side for me. However, when I got it home and assembled, I noticed that the one of brackets that holds the charcoal tray lifts was missing (it had 3 of 4), there was a worn spot on the top that went right to the bare metal and the bottom was again slightly warped- the grates didn't rest properly on it. I had to disassemble the unit (I don't own a truck, so getting it in my vehicle means disassembling...) and had Lowes (again) replace it. This time the entire grill was exchanged. 

Do NOT simply rush into assembly (like I did) in the excitement of getting into building it. That said: a company manufacturing a product ought to have better standards and inspection before its product leaves the plant. Returns like that are costly.

Yes, that's why I only gave it 3 stars. It took 3 trips top get it right when it should have taken one. I will update in the future once I've seen it perform over time.

Purchase the EPP, but be aware that if you exchange the grill, you have to purchase the EPP again for the new grill to be covered. It only covers ONE TIME EXCHANGE.
reviews.author: trptplayer

reviews.title: "Great purchase"
reviews.text: This grill has the best of both worlds, the convenience of gas and the great taste of charcoal. The assembly takes a bit over the hour suggested on the box, but the instructions are quite clear and easy to follow. The gas grill works well and gets very hot very quickly so often you only need one burner, especially if you work with the lid closed. The charcoal side is great because you can lower and raise the charcoal easily, but I have found that controlling the temperature is a bit of a challenge. I did discover that it takes less charcoal than my other grills though which is a plus. If you spread the hot coals thinly over the charcoal tray and close the air intake and the smoke stack, it will stay at a cozy 300-325 degrees for long term smoking.A great feature that I use a bunch is the side burner. I haven't used it to cook, but it was designed so you can put a charcoal starting can over it and use the gas to light the charcoal. AWESOME!Really the only issue I have with it is the temperature control on the charcoal side. (I have become accustomed to my Weber Kettle from the mid 1970's) Once I get past that learning curve, I don't envision any issues with the grill. If there is an issue that cannot be remedied by learning the unit, it is the length of the entire unit. It is quite long (about 6 feet), but that should be expected with a double grill with an extra burner on the side.
reviews.author: hcctreeman

reviews.title: "Material Quality long term, 7 years, substandard"
reviews.text: I bought this at Lowe's about 7 years or so ago! In that 7 years I have had to replace all 6 grills, half the hardware and now I need to replace the charcoal holder, REALLY? Details; the hardware, nuts to be exact, started falling off after 18 months, maybe this was the stores fault that put it together IDK, but they didn't supply the hardware, the manufacture did. What I'm saying they should have supplied heat locknuts to stay on instead of falling off inside the burner area. Next; the grills coating started peeling off after about 3.5 years and the store didn't have them in stock but could order them for me. Sounded ok until the price of them were $50 A PIECE. 6 of those is $300 and I could just buy another grill and have money left over!! Luckily Lowe's found a substitute for half that after a couple of months! For a while one of the charcoal hold trays bar where the side hook catches charcoal holder broke and I've been living with this for a while, a year I'll guess. But now there are holes in it where the heat has eat away the metal and that's just wrong. I have stored this on my porch the entire time with a cover on it (which by the way I'm on my 2nd one now because it sucks too) with no rain getting on it, and it needs replace. A grill should last 10 years or longer, at least, I use this 15 to 20 times a year and I'm tried of replacing things on it. One other thing; this grill will NOT stop the charcoal from burning up completely after you close the lid, charcoal I should be able to reuse, saves money from buying more and starts the next fire faster, but not on this one! I have an empty nest now but before, I use to cook almost every weekend during the summer for the family!P.S. Something about me;I did 20 years in the Navy and I came out 60% disabled.What I essentially did was defended the Judicial Branch, the Legislative Branch, the Executive Branches of our government.I feel I have earned every right this country has given its citizens.
reviews.author: FC1SWPAPPYS

reviews.title: "Great Grill for the Price"
reviews.text: This grill gets very hot on the propane side (almost 700 degrees on mine) and should not be left unattended once firing it up for a good preheat. With that said, for $300 you get modern day convenience with old school taste. Just remember to clean it out periodically, not every time so you keep the "flavor". There's so much room if you want to use both sides of the grill that I have hosted parties and fed well over 30 people easily in less that two hours of grilling. The design for the airflow is also excellent as the vents are designed to give you the option of adding a smoker box or simply setting your meat off to the side of the large grates to actually barbeque, not just grill. The simple Weber types are only for grilling and not truly a BBQ pit since your meat is always over the heat source.You also need to purchase the custom cover, which is reasonable and well made, if your grill is not under a covered area. It will rust quickly if left exposed to the elements. I have been through 3 of these BBQ's in the last 7 years. First one made it four years, second two #the metal felt like it was thinner than the last# and the last was my own fault since I was procrastinating keeping the gas side grease and dripping free. Left it while pre-heating and came back outside 5 minutes later to a propane fueled fireball that would not burn out. The extended warranty that Lowe's sells for this BBQ is outstanding. I burned mine down after 1 year of use and had a new BBQ in my back yard the next day. I cook outside year round and at least twice a week sometimes for extended periods, this grill is worth every penny! For the use I get out of this BBQ if I have to replace it every 3 years, it's still a bargain.
reviews.author: GrillGuard

reviews.title: "Great Grill for the price"
reviews.text: I have had my 5050 with side fire box for 9 years now and it has been a great grill. I average using it 1-2 times per week and have smoked briskets, baby backs, turkeys, salmon, shrimp, boston butts, whole pork shoulders, chicken wings, and cooked the usual steaks, burgers, etc. I have to say up front that the negative reviews about rust will happen if you don't take the time to season the grill according to directions and/or leave it out in the open weather. I have taken reasonable care of mine by keeping it seasoned with vegetable oil (on the outside usually twice a year and the cooking grates every cook) and when it was out in the weather I kept it covered (it's under an open sided shed now).It's just now rusting thru the left side of the bottom where I regularly bank the lit charcoal when cooking over direct heat. I only use the gas side now when the wife says, "I want porkchops in 20 minutes!" but when I used it more the grease shields over the burners rusted away after 5 years, not too bad and I rarely cleaned those. The fire box has held up well. I can say that if you over heat the fire box it will blister the paint but that's the user's fault and would happen in anything except cast iron. I use a charcoal chimney for starting all my fires and the "minion" method of building fire for long smokes and can get about 6 hours at 260F with just adding chunks of wood along the way to keep the smoke rolling. This probably has contributed to the longevity of the grill. Bottom line - If you are the person who cooks your food then walks away from the grill leaving it out in the weather year round get a city slicker stainless grill. If you are a person who is serious about smoking and charcoal cooking with the occasional need for a "quickie" with gas and take reasonable care of your equipment get the 5050 and the side fire box. You'll be glad you did. P.S.-The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is one of the ash pan hangers broke a spoke 3 years after I bought it.
reviews.author: Spicewood Valley Smoker

reviews.title: "5yrs later & STILL as in LOVE as the day we met!"
reviews.text: While I've had two grill covers that have succumbed to the elements over five years of this grill sitting outside multiple houses, my CharGriller Duo is still sturdy and going strong. I tell people anytime the topic of grilling comes up that having the gas/charcoal option is simply amazing. During the busy week, when I get home late from work, or even during a rainstorm, the gas is quick, easy, and clean way to get cooking fast and clean. Perfect control for searing tuna, too. But for weekend cookouts, when I want to smoke something or have a more richly-flavored feast and I've got the time, the charcoal delivers a truly wonderful cooking experience. I've also used both grilling sides at the same time for larger events. Great options to adjust height and ventilation in/out on the charcoal side. Bonus that the instruction manual came with a solid introductory guide to grilling, that helped me grow more advanced in my grilling techniques. While heavy, wheeling the grill to the other side of the deck to be more downwind of guests is an easy feat, and I've used the wheels more than I would have thought. I'll note, however, that I can't really attest to the efficacy of the side burner, as I really only use it for food prep. For maintenance, besides keeping my cover on, I try and oil the grill every year or year and a half, and will often do one side while I'm waiting on food from the other side. Grease and ash traps work really well, and are quick to empty.  While my wife thought the Duo was ugly ("big, black barrels in our backyard"), especially compared to some fancy stainless things, the flexibility and practicality of this grill quickly won her over. Neither of us would imagine switching to anything else now, and giving up the flexibility and durability that the Duo offered. 5.5 years later, I would buy this grill again in a heartbeat. (Side note: I think it's worth investing the ~$10 for a gas gauge. I only have one tank at a time, and once placed underneath the grill, it can be awkward to try and pick up the can to see how much is left by weight.)
reviews.author: Dave

reviews.title: "Love the versatility"
reviews.text: I bought this grill last week and I have only used it once, but I am impressed with this grill. I went ahead and bought the side firebox that doubles as a portable grill. I smoked a Boston butt the first day I had it and it came out perfect! Ok. I had a little help from a meat thermometer, but keeping the coals going and the smoke flowing was a breeze with this grill.I read a lot of the previous reviews on this grill, including the negative reviews, and I can tell you this grill is everything it is intended. The only con I have overall is one fairly minor thing, and I admit I may have missed it in the manual, when you're assembling this grill make sure the gas line going to the side burner is threaded through the side of the support bars. After putting mine together 100% (it took quite a while# I seasoned it and got it ready to burn for a couple of hours as the instructions state. I went to hook up my LP tank, and I had the gas line going around the front of the support bar. I'm afraid over time this is going to ruin the line. So now, before I use the gas side of the grill, I'll have to take the side burner off, thread it through and then reattach it. It would have been much easier to thread the control panel through the side while I was putting it together. If you take nothing else away from this review, take that advice.Anyway, back to the good. I love to grill and I love that this grill gives you all the options. On my days off I like to slow cook ribs and chicken in the smoker. On days I work, I like to cook steaks on the gas side #as I'll be doing tonight my wife has informed me :-) ). If you're serious about outdoor cooking you can't go wrong with this grill; especially for this price. If you have the means, take advantage of the free assembly. By "means" I mean if you have access to a truck. Those guys have probably put 100's of these together and can probably get it done in less than 5 hours. I actually enjoyed putting mine together, but I know not everyone shares my amusement.One last pro, and I'll quit boring you. Invest in a chimney charcoal starter. The side burner is designed in such a way the chimney starter fits right over the burner and does a fantastic job starting charcoal.
reviews.author: Stve5150

reviews.title: "This grill is awesome"
reviews.text: Ok here goes, I purchased this grill and fire box about 3 years ago and have used it just about 2 or 3 time a week year round. I thought I knew grilling before but after I got this one, I realized I was wrong. First let me start with the side burner. I use this feature mostly for starting my charcoal in a chimney charcoal starter and it works great. I have also used it to cook bacon, sausage, eggs, fried chicken and fish. A real asset if one doesn't want to smell up the house with fried foods.Next is the gas grill. I use this side mostly during the week when I want to grill but don't have time for charcoal. One can control the heat very well and with 3 burners the heat can be regulated very well. This side is also very good for searing steaks before slowing cooking them to perfection. I also use this side when I'm cooking vegetables and the top rack is prefect for grilling corn on the cob. The top rack is also good for toasting buns for hamburgers and hot dogs.Now for my favorite part, the charcoal side and fire box a must. Now this grill has 3 grates on each side so putting charcoal in and lighting or charcoal that is already going very easy. The grill cooks very evenly and with the large cooking area one can cook a lot of food. I have had up to 4 full racks of ribs going at one time. The one thing that I had to do on the charcoal side was remove the top rack to cook larger pieces like Boston Butts. The temperature can be regulated very well using the dampers on the top and on the side, I can hold the temperature at 225 to 250 very easily. If I decide to cook directly over the coals that works good too. the coal can be raised and lower by the handles on each side. So if one wants to cook over the coals or slow cook, it can be done easily.Now for a few down sides, this grill is not bullet proof. It will wear out as I found out this year, 2014 but I did use it a WHOLE lot. It doesn't have a lot of space to set plates and cooking utensils on. The grease shield over the gas burners will burn out with a lot of use. And if this grill is to be moved around very much, it gets heavy. With it only having wheels at one end one has to lift the other end. I also bought the fitted grill cover and it was a complete waste. Go ahead and get the generic cover, you'll be glad you did.So if someone ask me if I would buy this grill again? You bet I will.And one last note on this grill that I have found out is, It works very well when I have a cold beer when I'm grillin'
reviews.author: Chad

questions.question: "How does this product hold up if its covered but on an uncovered deck. Will it start to rust?"
questions.author: Anonymous

answers.author: LagunaHillsTom
answers.text: I've happily owned this BBQ for over 3 years...maybe 4. It has been on an uncovered deck and I've tried to keep it covered all the time...but it hasn't. It, by far, is the best BBQ i've ever owned! I use the charcoal side the most, so that side has zero rust. The gas side has a small amount of rust but it goes away when you use it and cook on that side. You should definetely get it. If and when mine starts to get too old..I will be re-buying this grill again...but it doesn't look like it's going to happen for awhile.

answers.author: DAWN
answers.text: yes yes yes I have only had this grill for two 1/2 years and rusted out and the top bolt area broke so the lid will not open or close properly now. I always kept it covered. Do not Buy

answers.author: Libby
answers.text: Living in southeast Louisiana, the heat plates rusted out too easily. Grill is under a carport. Replacement parts are easy to order. Just have your model# ready.

answers.author: Cletus
answers.text: I have had mine for 7 years in snow and heat of Indiana. A little high heat paint and she looks good. I haven't had any problems like other people claim to have.

answers.author: MT
answers.text: Mine rusted away to literally nothing in 3 years. We live in a costal environment. I've never seen anything rust so fast. The bottom is actually gone completely. Went to the dump this week

answers.author: Kris10
answers.text: Yes! Read the negative reviews. I wish I had before I bought it. Mine is covered and on a covered carport and started to rust the first year. Ive had it 2 years now and have to replace the grates and the flame cover.

answers.author: DJC
answers.text: I've had mine for 9 years and its finally time to retire it. Its a great value. I will pick up another one in a couple of weeks.

answers.author: tlw
answers.text: Ive had mine since 2009. Seldom used and always under a covered patio. The tabs that hold the burner shields above the burner tubes are crumbling but only on the center burner. still usable for the time being. heat and moisture will eventually cause it to rust completely out

answers.author: MrM3000
answers.text: As mentioned by many other reviewers and from my own personal experience, this grill will rust out in about 2-3 years no matter what you do. I'm meticulous about reading manuals and followed the recommended oiling intervals, keeping it covered with the custom black cover (which is not impermeable btw, and will last about a year before itself disintegrates into an unsightly grayish material), etc, but no matter what I did, rust eventually did develop and by now (about 6 years later) it's falling apart. The electronic igniter also failed after about 3 years, as well as one of the three gas knobs. Some may disagree, and that's fine, but I'm just saying that was MY experience.

answers.author: RobH
answers.text: I have had this grill for almost 2 years in these conditions. I try to recover it as soon as it cools off, but there have been a few nights where it started raining or I forgot and didn't want to cover it wet. It has minimal rust, but be sure to coat it occasionally with oil as it stated in the instructions. I bought a couple cans of spray olive oil and coat it well about every 6 months. It has held up very well so far.

answers.author: SchlupRae
answers.text: Yes. It is not stainless steel and (even with extrensive seasoning and covering) it will rust. It usually takes between 3-4 years, so get the Lowe's 3-4 year warranty.

answers.author: Char-Griller Support
answers.text: It is dependent upon care, maintenance and use. The grill is made of steel but is not stainless. We recommend coating any bare metal surfaces with a light coating of oil to help prevent rust.

answers.author: Plaindriver
answers.text: I got mind in the fall of '12. It lives outdoors but under a covered patio. Never the less, it does have some signs of rust on some edges. Also, the three sheet metal burner covers disintegrated basically. Rust + heat. I got a replacement set on ebay for about $25 in stainless steel. BTW, I have mine converted to use 'city' gas instead of the propane tank.

answers.author: Tsheetz
answers.text: Read once before from a previous owner said it would. But steel is heavy And I'm sure it would take years.

questions.question: "Does this come with a gauge to tell when you are running low on propane?"
questions.author: Anonymous

answers.author: Nikki
answers.text: Most Webber grills have gauges

answers.author: GatorRay
answers.text: As a practical matter none of the fixed or inline propane gauges are accurate. The stick on variety that detects temp differences is also a crude attempt to gauge the remaining liquified gas. Another way is to disconnect the hose from the tank, step on your bathroom scale with the tank of unknown quantity and see how the wt differs when it was just filled. Oh, you forgot to weigh it after you filled it? Darn! If you turned in your partially filled tank because your last inaccurate gauge said it was empty then you probably didn't get a full fill. It's just not accurate trying to guess. The best method is to run the grill until the tank empties and it flames out then switch to your spare full tank then re-light before the grill cools off. A pain but no waste. Most places refilling charge by the weight at the end of the refill. If it was 1/4 full you wind up paying for the old as well as the new gas. Some charge the difference of the pre- and post refill. If you exchange tanks based on one of those inaccurate online or stick on gauges you will be likely be more Blue than the company since you just gave them a partially filled tank and exchanged it for the full over-priced exchange tank. Try the big "C" next time for 1/2 the cost of the refill.

answers.author: Tsheetz
answers.text: No but you can purchase them or about 20.00 almost anywhere.

answers.author: Mark
answers.text: No it does not -I always just keep a spare bottle around.

answers.author: cspelliott
answers.text: It does not come with a gauge for the propane.

answers.author: RobH
answers.text: No, but I use the additional gas gauge as posted by the other user. It is about $20 not on sale. Item #: 231786 Model #: 80064L Indicates how much propane is left in a propane tank Connects between a type 1 propane regulator and a type 1 propane tank fitting Side note. I'm in a colder climate (PA) and in the winter, the gas condenses in the bottle and it reads almost empty, but in the summer the same amount reads almost full. This is not foolproof depending on the outside temperature. I thought all of my bottles were almost empty, but an unused one that read almost empty in the winter actually read mostly full in the summer.

answers.author: hokiejoe
answers.text: The Duo or "50 50", as it is frequently known, does not have a gas volume gage included but most stores sell a device that actually is installed between the Propane bottle and the regulator to indicate fuel level

answers.author: Nickname
answers.text: It does not.

questions.question: "I just purchased the Charcoal/Gas Grill #5050, do you need to use ceramic charcoal briquettes on the gas side, it doesn't have anything to hold them."
questions.author: Pengy

answers.author: nissandude
answers.text: No need to. It has a heat distribution plate.

answers.author: Assembler2587
answers.text: Any use of charcoal briquettes should stay on the charcoal side and not the gas side. That is why you don't see a place to put and briquettes. The only recommend I would go with is to season your grates before using them that way they last longer and add flavor to your food.

answers.author: Anonymous
answers.text: No, the ceramic briquettes are old technology. The flavor shields over the burners will work just fine.

answers.author: MajorSmeg
answers.text: You do not need the ceramic briquettes.

answers.author: Marty357
answers.text: You don't need to use the briquettes at all on the gas side. I use a chip smoking box on the gas side every so often for added flavor, do most of my cooking on the charcoal side. Ususally do potatoes, veggies, burgers and dogs with the gas. I really don't believe its necessary to add the briquettes. Hope this helps.

questions.question: "My gas burners aren't lighting, do I replace them (3)? if so, what's the model number, etc and cost?"
questions.author: Anonymous

answers.author: RetiredCoach
answers.text: You can google CharGriller replacement parts and order igniters. But first, check your batteries. Probably not making a spark. Or just get a long lighter and keep it handy.

answers.author: Griller
answers.text: Check www.chargriller.com

answers.author: Steve
answers.text: Unlikely that all the sparkers at the burners are out at once so the piezo starter button is the likely culprit. Go underneath your burner control panel. Are all the wires plugged into the lighter button? Unplug and replug a few times to clean the connections. Test it. Still not working? Unplug wires, press starter button while watching underneath side of it(Propane off). Is there spark between the terminals? If no- replace piezo starter button.

answers.author: Char-Griller Support
answers.text: I would suggest calling us at 912-638-4724 to troubleshoot. It could be something as simple as the safety device in your propane tank! Please give us a call and we will be happy to help you with it.

questions.question: "If you add the smoker to this Duo-Char-Griller to make it a 3 unit piece is there a cover made for it by someone?"
questions.author: Anonymous

answers.author: RobH
answers.text: Yes, this cover has a Velcro piece that expands if you have the smoke box attached. It fits extremely well but is not shown in the item picture, but says so in the description. Item# 287133

answers.author: Ctlman
answers.text: The standard cover for the Duo will work with the smoker. When the smoker is not attached to the Duo, the part of the cover which would cover the smoker collapses and is held closed by Velcro strips.

answers.author: Nick
answers.text: Yes, the cover that is sold fits the entire unit. It is designed to be closed with Velcro, if the firebox is not attached. It is a very good, custom made cover. To better explain it; the end of the cover that covers the firebox is simply folded and attached to the end of the cover, then secured flat by Velcro.

answers.author: Char-Griller Support
answers.text: Yes, the covere offered for the Duo also fits it with the firebox attached. The cover # is 8080 and it is $42.99 before shipping on our website.
